label: Letter 1 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, March 11, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, addressing the allegations leveled against him in the last letter he had received from Gertrude. Sidney tells her that he was not trying to rush her off the phone, urges her to give up on her attempts to join him in Hawaii, as the Navy has figured out all the tricks and she would not be allowed, and stressing to her how much he does love and miss her.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, addressing the allegations leveled against him in the last letter he had received from Gertrude. Sidney tells her that he was not trying to rush her off the phone, urges her to give up on her attempts to join him in Hawaii, as the Navy has figured out all the tricks and she would not be allowed, and stressing to her how much he does love and miss her.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
11 
 March 11, 1945,
Gertle Darling,
What a letter that was, your No 74 of March
1st. It arrived this morning two days after your letter
of March 3rd. and completely bowled me over. I have read it
over about twenty times and can only come to the conclusion
that you were terribly tired and nervous when youwrote it.
Let us take up some of the things you say in
the order that they were written. First yousay that I was in
a hurry to ring off. I was not in a hurry to ring off but
told you goodbye because I could not hear anything you were
saying. As I stated in a last letter everytime I started to
tell youabout the swimming and surfboarding that morning
you would say "are you in the water" or something like that.
In the end I thought it must hold some meaning and was some
form of code and told you that I did not understand what it
was about. During the entire coversation your voice would
fade sway and I would hear nbthing and then suddenly lt would
come back after a while and you would be talking about something
of which I had missed half the point. You know how I really
dislike the phone and then on top of that to be unable to say
very much without the censor cutting us off makes a normal
conversation impossible. Frankly I get much more out of
your letters than the phone.
Secondly you say you do not care how terrible
Tozzer is, all that you want to be is out here. I realize
you want to be out here because I want to be with youdear,
and I have tried to get youout here but with no results.
When I asked my captain he said , if you will tell me how
to get my wife out. Colonel Laswell of the Marines who I
thought might know saldhe had been trying to get his wife out
for eight months. There are three boys in the office that
,have done everything they can and have now given up hope. You
have been told these things by me before but apparently do not
believe them. There are thousands of men in the service out
here that want their wives out just as I want mine but this
is the Navy. You are a civilian and cannot realize how free
you are and how we are held up by directives and orders. If
you_want to qultoyou can quit now, the best I can hope for is
six months after the end of the war. But there is absolutley
no use my going into this again. I have done it in so many lett
ers. I really tried to explain; to you that the Navy does not
want any wives out,that there is nothing that I can do, but
you interprett it as my not loving youany more. How can you
[End Page 1]
say such a thing dear, how can youhave so little faith. Just 
think how you would feel if I wrote youand said "you do not
love me anymore" when you lovemeso much . I think it would 
make you feel very sad to know your love was doubted that the
person you cared for did not have sufficent faith in you to
believe you could continue loving them although you were
seperatred because of a war. I do not know what our past life
has meant to you Gertie. In everyway I have tried to do the
thing that would please you, I tried to hunt on those dam horses
I gave up all ideas of business, I went on expeditions, we
toured Europe in Motor cars until I thought my back would break
g and I was so happy to do it because those thlngs pleased you.
Now because our country is at war and I am trying to do my best
out here, and have been unable to get you out you say I do
not love you. It is all beyond me and I seriously Wonder who
I have been married to, is it some one who is so selfish that
she upbraids me the first timesI cannot accede to her wish
because it is beyond my power.
Gertie I have told youhow I have missed you in any
number of letters. How I wished you were with me swimming
walking ln the moonlight lying by my side in the evening. But
I if I had not, what difference. You ought to know without
constant repepetition that I love and adore you and you should
feel sure enough of me not to need continual assurance on my
part that I love you. If you don't Gertie then you miss one
of the great things in life. There is no doubt in my mind 
about you, all the people in the world could talk against you,
I could go without hearing from you for ten years but at the
end I would still love and feel you loved me. 
I wanted to yarn you about Toozer. To let you
know what youwere getting yourself in for so that you could
try to get out some other way without comprising yourself.
Yesterday we received an order that we were no longer to give
OSS any further information, so youcan see that he is non
persona grata. You took this warning as a sign on my part
that I did not want you here. I am so sorry that you could
shave thought that [my] love for you has failed. It is the one
strong thing in my life, the one thing I have clung to and
from your letter I gather it hasn't been very impressive.
Nevertheless you still have it sweetheart.
Sidney
[End Page 2]
